newsitem.title: POLAND: EU envoy questions extent of Polish media freedom.
newsitem.headline: EU envoy questions extent of Polish media freedom.

text.p: The European Union representative in Warsaw raised questions on Thursday over the extent of freedom of the news media, notably of television, in Poland.

Rolf Timans said the European Commission, would probe media freedom and other controversial issues in a report on how well Poland is prepared for accession -- the "avis" -- due to be ready by mid-1997.
"There are several question marks as regards freedom of media, especially television," Timans wrote in an article published on Thursday in the Rzeczpospolita daily.
He said other issues the Commission would examine closely in its report included civilian control over the armed forces and accessibility of the justice system to the average citizen.
"Certain problems are to be noticed in the sphere of legislation and the justice system," Timans wrote.
The Commission's avis will be the base for accession talks, which Poland hopes to begin early next year so it can join the community around the year 2000 or 2002.
Brussels diplomats say that 2002 is the earliest realistic entry date for Poland and other former Soviet bloc countries aspiring to join, such as the Czech Republic and Hungary.

Poland's right-centrist opposition charges that the ruling leftist coalition of ex-communists and a Peasant party has grabbed substantial influence over public television, the country's main source of news, and aims to use it in the campaign for this year's parliamentary elections.

Earlier this year, a group of journalists and other employees published a letter, protesting against alleged attempts to politicise public television and the chaos stemming from frequent changes of management.
The changes began last year when the right-leaning head of the television Wieslaw Walendziak quit, alleging pressure from the two ruling parties.
Since then many senior television managers have quit or been fired and some hard-hitting current affairs programmes associated with the former management have been scrapped.
